Posts.Content: Mar 30, 2010 06:01PM SusanR wrote: I went the route of lumpectomy and lymph node removal and then 2 weeks later, both breasts removed.  The first surgery was without a doubt the worst as the armpit pain was a killer.  The actually mastectomies were not difficult at all, just the bothersome drains and keeping track of which was which so I could log their output. Wear comfy button down shirts and elastic waist pants.  I found that using a safety pin helped me clip my drain tubes to a shoelace I wore around my neck and  worked great for in the shower and after for hairstyling etc.  Keep everything within arms reach and set yourself up a nice little nest where you sit so you have everything you need close by.  I was driving  in a week or so. Good luck with everything, Let us know how it goes. SusanR

Posts.Content: SusanR wrote: Hi all, I was having some pretty bad back pain and my Onc ordered an MRI of my spine.  Had it done Tuesday and it showed multiple bone mets in the spine.  I then had a Bone Scan on Thursday that showed bone mets to the base of my skull, a rib and 3 vertebra.  These spots are all new since my last scan in June that showed no bone mets.  My history is of a hip met in 2008 that required a total hip replacement in 2009.  I had a 3 year run on Femara and Zometa, pretty good from what I understand.  I'm ER+/PR-/Her2-. Friday afternoon I had a CT Scan of the chest abdomen and pelvis and those were all clean.  Of course I'm thrilled for that but am blown away by 5 new bone mets since June.  I'm having trouble taking it in and wrapping my head around it. I always knew I was one of the lucky ones to have a single bone met and now I'm wondering if my luck just ran out? Does this put me in the pool with all the other statistics now? Even though I don't hang on those stats, of course I think of them. I'll be starting on Faslodex this week and will continue the Zometa. I'm scared, I'm sad, I'm having trouble focusing. I'm thinking about giving up the full time stressful job, I think it might be time?  So many thoughts are racing around in my head.  How long before it goes to a vital organ?  What's the average run on Faslodex?  Thanks for being here.  You are all the best!! SusanR IDC 2002 Stage II Grade 3 4/29 nodes ER/PR+ Her2- Stage IV Dec 2008 Bone ER+/PR-/Her2- Bone Progression Oct.2011 to Spine,Skull and Rib Dx 11/22/2002, IDC, Stage IIIC, Grade 3, 4/29 nodes, mets, ER+/PR+, HER2- Surgery 11/25/2002 Lumpectomy: Right; Lymph node removal: Right, Sentinel; Mastectomy: Left, Right; Prophylactic mastectomy: Left; Reconstruction (left): DIEP flap; Reconstruction (right): DIEP flap Chemotherapy 1/7/2003 Cytoxan (cyclophosphamide), Taxotere (docetaxel) Chemotherapy 1/7/2003 Adriamycin (doxorubicin) Chemotherapy 1/7/2003 Cytoxan (cyclophosphamide) Radiation Therapy 7/5/2003 Breast Radiation Therapy 1/20/2009 Bone Hormonal Therapy 10/10/2011 Faslodex (fulvestrant) Targeted Therapy 12/1/2016 Ibrance (palbociclib) Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Oct 24, 2011 12:21PM SusanR wrote: Thanks for all the great responses!  I love this place!  I will find out my schedule for the Faslodex this week and am anxious to get started as I know it can take a while to see if it's working.  I have spent the weekend talking to friends and family and coming to terms with this new situation I find myself in. I had recently begun thinking about leaving work even before these scans that showed progression.  I've worked for the same company for 25 years and they have been extremely good to me.  I work in healthcare, in an administrative type job that involves mostly patient information and auditing charts so working from home is not a viable option as I can't take patient info out of the hospital.  I also commute an hour each way to work.  Those 2 hours of driving (longer in the winter) and an 8-10 hour day are sapping the heck out of me, even on days when I feel good. Though I have loved my job and have excelled at my career, I found myself living scan to scan and telling myself that I would let work go if I had any type of progression.  It was a bargaining tool I was using to continue in a frustrating stressful job.  Also, I have not wanted to leave the world of work too soon.  You know how you feel like you have a foot in each world? One in the work world and one in the staying home and enjoying whatever life holds for me world?  I don't want to leave either world too soon.  If I leave work and live a long time will it be a financial burden?  If I don't leave work and the cancer progresses quickly for me, will I  miss the chance I might have had to spend quality time with granchildren etc.  So my bargaining tool has come to light.  I find myself having progression and feeling like I need to be true to myself.  Progression has come and I told myself I would stop working and live life outside of work.  I think I've already made the decision, the question is when?  I want to finish things up, I coordinate a yearly medical symposium that is in mid November and is one of the highlights of what I do well.  I'm thinking I'll talk to my financial guy and a benefits coordinator with the hospital to find out if based on any benefit changes it's best to go out before the end of the year or in the beginning of the new year. Just typing this out makes me feel better.  Thanks all for being here. Much love, SusanR

Posts.Content: Jun 28, 2011 10:06AM SusanR wrote: rosasmommy, I find myself grieving for the person I used to be .That person who felt well enough to do so many things I can't do now, that person who knew that death could snatch me up at any time, but really didn't look at it head on like I do now because I don't have the luxury of being blissfully ignorant.  I miss my old self; the one who had Estrogen in her body and a uterus and ovaries, the one who didn't worry about an a new ache or pain being a signal that the cancer is spreading. The woman who didn't need the equivelant of general anesthesia just to shut my mind off and fall asleep every night!  And yet, every day i look at my life as the new normal.  The old normal is gone and with each step of this reality, there is a new normal.  It changes every day and sometimes I find myself chasing it and other days I find myself content where I am.  Thanks for starting this topic, Thinking of and accepting that much of this cancer CRAP (for Konokat!!) is a grieving process helps me immensely. Much love, Sue

Posts.Content: Jan 17, 2013 12:32AM - edited Jan 17, 2013 12:33AM by SusanR Hello Ladies! I'm 56 and after 26 years as a Registered Nurse, went out on disability/retirement in Dec, 2011.  I have one son (33) and fabulous DIL with baby number 3 coming in May.  I am also a surrogate mom/gramdma to my niece (37) and her 2 children since my sister died at 44 and my niece was only 19 and still needed a "mom".  She and my son and their families are my joy in life.  I am married, but in name as only he's an active alcoholic and I can't seem to leave him behind after 38 years of marriage and the need for financial and insurance benefits (that sounds terrible doesn't it???) but I'll save that for another post! I was diagnosed Stage IIB in 2002 and had bilateral mastectomy, chemo and radiation.  Had bilateral DIEP reconstruction in New Orleans in 2006 (fabulous!) and in 2008 became Stage IV with single bone mets to hip which was replaced in 2009.  Treated with Femara and Zometa until multiple new bone mets in spine, skull and rib were found in 2011 them switched to Fasolodex and Zometa and have been stable since.  Made the decision to enjoy life after that and went out on permanent Disabiliity in late Dec of 2011 and have not a single moment of regret about leaving work.  I love being home and being a Grandma and doing things with friends and family.  Vacationed in Hawaii, Cancun, Omaha to see my sister and Virginia for my Aunt's 95th Birthday in 2012 and am planning an Alaskan Cruise this summer. Cashed in on a substantial Life Insurance policy from employer using Accelerated Benefits and I am making some financial plans for the future but I'm also enjoying a sigh of relief financially.  If not for this group of ladies I would never have known about the option of taking my Life Insurance early! I am so blessed to have found this group and to have the knowledge, support and compassion of each of them in whatever way possible. Much love, SusanR

Posts.Content: SusanR wrote: I got my scan results today and the bone mets are all stable and no new areas of mets.  I am just so relieved and so thankful to all of you ladies for helping me through the last few days.  It was one of my worst scanxiety attacks in all these years of dealing with this crap and I don't know what I would do without you gals, you are just the best! I have been dealing with a kidney stone that shows up on every CT.  For a few years it was 2-3 mms and not obstructing anything, then it was 4mms, in April it was 8mms and I saw a Urologist who said since it's not bothering anything we could watch it a few more months.  Well it's now 12mms or 1.2cms.  I think the little bas@#$tard is going to have to go soon and I'm not relishing the idea of having it blasted.  Did all of that in 2007 and it was a mess cuz' it wouldn't break up and eventually I had to have surgery to go up into the kidney and blast it from inside.  I guess this falls under the category of "if it's not one thing, it's another".   Again, my lovely ladies, thanks for your words of support and hope while I was waiting for my scans, it means the world to me to know you are here. Posts.Content: SusanR wrote: Question for any of you with Pevic Bone Mets.  I was diagnosed with Bone Mets in Dec. 2008 and in June 2009 I had a hip replacement for stress fractures that wouldn't heal.  I am now having serious pain in my lower pelvic bone that feels similar and hurts mostly when I take a step.  I'm not in much pain when I am sitting quietly.  I saw my Ortho  last Monday because of the pain but at the time it was mostly generalized in the hip area and he put me on anti-inflammatories thinking it sounded like bursitis.  When he was looking at the X-Ray he seemed focused on the hardware and hip parts he had replaced to be sure nothing had shifted or moved out of whack.  In fact it wasn't until he was done looking and had shut the machine off that he asked me why he did the hip replacement,  maybe assuming it  was for arthritis.  When I told him it was for Stage IV he said he didn't see anything alarming. I'm thinking I should call the office tomorrow and ask him to look again to be sure there isn't a small fracture in my pelvis that he might not have been looking for. What do you ladies think?  Anyone with pelvic mets have pain that resolves when sitting or lying down?  The anti-inflammatory is definitely helping with the generalized hip pain, but not the pelvic pain, in fact that seems a bit worse with each day and it all started on Mother's Day so that's a few weeks now. I know I'm answering my own questions here and will call tomorrow and see if I get some answers.  Maybe just putting it in writing was enough to sound my own alarms!!  Would love to hear from any of you even if just for moral support! Thanks for being here. Posts.Content: SusanR wrote: OK friends, talk me down off the ledge please:)  Tomorrow morning, Thurs, I am having my bone scan and then CT of the chest, abdomen and pelvis.  I haven't had these scans since 6 months ago and those were stable.  It was last October that showed progression to the spine, skull and a rib.  I've been stable for 1 year now and there is a little devil sitting on my shoulder telling me that the stable is over and the shit will hit the fan.  I have no basis for thinking that other than is it time for another shoe to drop?  This is of course attached to the scans and a little increaed back pain.  I have bone involvement only so far and am on Zometa and Fasolodex. My first recurrence to the hip was in 2008, so Im almost 4 years into this Stage IV crap and like so many others, I"m wondering when the beginning of the end will rear it's ugly head.  I want to believe I'm being dramatic and the scans will remain stable, but the waiting, the mental nutness, the willingness to go to the ugly pleace and then picturing myself pn the ledge waiting to get the results.  I haven't jumped yet,, and don't think i will, but going goofy is definetley an optionn  So here I am asking all of you to be with me while I wait and while i go to the dark places all the while praying for more time!  Thank you for always being here and holding my hand!  s I have an appointment for the results next Tuesday, but think I'll call the Onc office on Friday ando k the Doc to give me the report over the phone, cuz I don't think I can wait that long!!  I have Ativan and i'm not afraid to use it!!  Just talk me through the next few days so I can feel your presence.  For some reason this one sems extra worrisome. Posts.Content: Jan 31, 2012 04:28PM SusanR wrote: Hi I'm SusanR and I originally found this site a few years after my Stage IIB diagnosis.  I didn't really post, just looked around a bit.  When I was diagnosed Stage IV with bone mets in 2008 I came here immediately and found this discussion board for Stage IVers.  I gathered as much info as I could and eventually posted a bit.  I now come here daily to see how everyone is and keep up with the latest. My Stage IV mets was originally to my right hip and I ended up having the hip replaced due to stress fractures that wouldn't heal.  I got a 3 year run on Femara and Zometa until this past October when I had progression to numerous bones, so now I'm on Fasolodex and Zometa and scans last week showed the bone mets are stable after 12 weeks on this treatment.  I'm hoping for another 3 year run or longer on this combo!!  I recently went on Disability from my full time job and I'm anxious about how it wil work financially, but my faith sustains me. I Love this site and I don't know how I would face this beast without all these lovely people to hold hands with every day!

Posts.Content: Oct 20, 2010 08:38AM SusanR wrote: Leah, I'm so glad the port is in and that's off your "to do and think about" list.  Do remember though, that port is yours and it's part of your body.  Don't let anyone inexperienced practice on you and be sure to ask them every time if it's been flushed properly.  I know that may make some people uncomfortable and as a nurse I can understand it from both the patient and the nurse perspective, but ask away.  My onc nurses now tell me when they are putting in the flushes and it puts my mind at rest.  The last thing you want to have is it clotting off and not useable. All things said, I think you'll love having the port! SusanR

Posts.Content: Jun 27, 2012 11:37PM SusanR wrote: Ann, my last day of work was December 3, 2012.  I adored my job and had been with the company 25 years.  I was a nurse and had climb the ladder into a dream office job with total control and independence with the job.  No one reported to me and I reported to one person.  I don't think I could have had a job better suited to me with a compay that took phenomenal care of their employees. That said, I knew leaving was the right thing for me.  I packed up walked out and have hardly looked back. Some financial worries have turned out OK and I am at peace.  I also have to pinch myself some mornings when I don't have to fight to make the one hour commute, find a parking space with 4000 other people, and then make the long trek into my office.  It was brutal and the work pace and stress were brutal.  I am still 6 months later trying to find my rhythhm.  Some days I think I have it figured out and can plan even the simplest of days and then pain or treatments  send everything out the window and I take a nap!!  And you know what?  Taking a nap is just fine and I'm thrilled to have the opportunity to do it!  I am convinced that I will live longer because I retired. You'll find your niche and your rhytthm too.  There are many meaningful things to do if that's your choice.  You'll figure it out.  In the meantime, just take it in and enjoy what feels like a vacation at first! SusanR

Posts.Content: Sep 22, 2010 09:21AM SusanR wrote: Lynn, thanks for your post.  I have just recently started doing Water Aerobics at my Health Club as I found with the mets to the hip and then the replacement, I can't pound it out on the treadmill anymore, the cost is just too high and I can't seem to pace myself as I always feel the need to go faster and do more.  Being in the water changes all of that and I "go with the flow" so to speak and just do what I can during the class.  I am finding my arms are stronger and I walk a little lighter now.  My Health Club fees are pretty steep so I am making myself get in the water 2x a week so I don't feel the money is wasted.  Exercise is not an easy thing to put on the prioirty list for me, but somehow I just have to.  I do find I feel very alive in the water also, so once I'm there, it's wonderful.  Good luck, keep us updated and inspired!!

Posts.Content: Apr 9, 2012 12:19AM SusanR wrote: Hi Fitz, yes a serious question to be sure on the Easter Evening!  I for one am deeply spiritual and by that I mean I am religious.  I think spiritual means different things to different people, but for me it means religion in every sense of who I am as a Christian.  Cancer hasn't necessarily made my faith stronger, as it was already, but what it has done is made it clearer to me.  Pain, suffering, fear etc. all cause me to lean on my Savior and to acknowledge that He is in charge here.  I feel fortunate in that I never felt the "why me" feelings.  If I accept all the beauty, all the blessings of this earthy life without question, then I too have to accept all the not so beautiful.  My prayers to God are mostly prayers of thanksgiving for all that I do have, but they are also for strength and courage to live out His will for me.  Sometimes my prayers are little more than a sigh, but God and I talk all the time, so he knows what I mean!! Much love, SusanR

Posts.Content: May 27, 2010 12:22PM SusanR wrote: Hi Tamara, you are not crazy, and it looks like you are very early into this journey; just diagnosed in February of this year right?.  Tamoxifen can do some intense things to our bodies and our Estrogen levels and that may be a big part of this.  Talk to your Oncologist and make sure he/she knows you are having a rough time.  Maybe the antidepressant needs to be adjusted while you adjust to your new reality??? I'm so sorry this is happening, but you are in the right place.  ((Much love))  SusanR
Posts.Title: Just CRYING.. llanabeth donnabee

Posts.Content: Jul 9, 2011 11:41AM SusanR wrote: Sue, another Sue here, there are lot's of Sue's on this forum!!  I'm so sorry for your news.  It is scarey isn't it?  I have bone mets that appeared in my hip in the fall of 2008.  Since that recurrence diagnosis I have been through many emotions and many scarey moments.  I am happy to say I am Stable and have been for 2 1/2+ years with Femara daily and Zometa infusions monthly.  Stay here with us and take it slow if that's humanly possible.  For me, I was already on Femara, they treated the hip with radiation and then started Zometa.  Unfortunately I had to have the hip replaced but that's long over and I'm still Stable.  No new mets since the hip.  You can be here many many years with bone mets and the treatment is certainly do-able. I wish you good luck.  I know it's hard but we'll all help you. Much love, SusanR
Posts.Title: I Guess It Was the Right Time 37antiques Reneepals

Posts.Content: Aug 13, 2010 12:59PM SusanR wrote: With bone mets to the hip resulting in a total hip replacement, I have had to give up the pounding on the treadmill.  For some reason when I get on that treadmill I just have to go further, faster and harder!!  So, now I do water aerobics and I love it!  I'm very fortunate that my health club has a pool and offers water aerobics 4 evenings a week.  I try to go at least 2 times each week.  I am amazed at how a person can "sweat like a pig" in the water.  I love how my body pain goes away when I am in the water, and I how alive it makes me feel. For that hour I forget I have cancer...... SusanR
